summary.attemptedFixes: The fix can be implemented by adding documentation to the Bazel Python Rules repository, specifically examples for common cases such as getting the current Python version, Python headers, and building strings for wheel file naming.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is currently labeled as 'Good first issue' and 'type: documentation', indicating it's a suitable issue for a contributor to tackle, especially for those new to the project.

issueDTO.title: a11y: forced colors support
issueDTO.description:
Windows and Firefox support "forced colors", the ability to override a website color palette with user-defined colors. Windows calls this "High-Contrast Mode"; Firefox exposes it in the "Manage Colors" modal of `about:preferences`.

Testing on Firefox 100 on Linux: forced colors causes vote arrows to render as white squares. I imagine the problem also exists on Windows High Contrast Mode. Here's a screenshot for reference:

![Comment thread in lobsters; the upvote arrow is a white rectangle over a dark background](https://seirdy.one/misc/lobsters_forced_colors.png).

Possible solutions, in descending order of desirability from my perspective:

- Render the upvote as an SVG. A simple static SVG-Tiny should do the trick.
- Render the upvote as a plain old PNG
- Render the upvote using icon fonts
comments:
Thanks for catching and reporting this bug.

For whoever picks this up: please go with SVG. We can use a css `filter` to change the color in dark mode.

On Tue, May 31, 2022 at 10:04:42AM -0700, Peter Bhat Harkins wrote:
>For whoever picks this up: please go with SVG. We can use a css 
>`filter` to change the color in dark mode.

An even better approach to adaptive coloring would be to just make the default vote arrows the foreground color (e.g. "Canvas") and slightly reduce their opacity. Dark mode text-color changes will then automatically carry over to arrow color changes, *and* it'll play very well with customizations ranging from forced-colors to custom userstyles. It'll also be easier to maintain by introducing one less dark-mode adjustment.

As for distinguishing the red arrows form the gray ones in a way that doesn't depend solely on color: that's a tricky one. Perhaps the icon itself could be altered or enlarged, or it could receive a visible CSS decoration.

The orange site has an interesting approach: it just hides the button but adds an "unvote" hyperlink to the comment's controls.

-- 
Seirdy

I was just reminded of this by the filing of 1641. Since the bug was filed, we changed how we draw the upvote arrows to use a unicode 25B2 rather than draw a shape with border/background colors.

@Seirdy can you confirm if this is still an issue for you? I tried to reproduce and couldn't, but the Firefox settings UI has changed from what you describe so I'm not certain I'm testing the same thing.

summary.attemptedFixes: Possible solutions include rendering the upvote as an SVG, a plain old PNG, or using icon fonts. A suggested approach is to use a CSS filter to change the color in dark mode. Another option is to make the default vote arrows the foreground color and slightly reduce their opacity, allowing for automatic color changes in dark mode.

issueDTO.title: [feature request] `supported_params` and `expected_outputs` for `cmd` provisioners
issueDTO.description:
Currently when we are doing 
```bash
score-compose init --provisioners https://raw.githubusercontent.com/score-spec/community-provisioners/refs/heads/main/score-k8s/10-redis-helm-upgrade.provisioners.yaml
```
the `score-compose provisioners list` don't display outputs because it is not supported 
```bash
+-------+-------+--------+---------+-------------+
| TYPE  | CLASS | PARAMS | OUTPUTS | DESCRIPTION |
+-------+-------+--------+---------+-------------+
| redis |       |        |         |             |
+-------+-------+--------+---------+-------------+
```

Leaving this one to anyone who would like to take the opportunity to tackle a `good first issue` and `help wanted` issue. The goal is to back port what was done in score-k8s there: https://github.com/score-spec/score-k8s/pull/156, in this repo here.

then
```bash 
go run cmd/score-compose/main.go provisioners list

+---------------+---------+------------------+--------------------------------+--------------------------------+

|               |         |                  |                                | pointing to this Redis         |
|               |         |                  |                                | Service.                       |
+---------------+---------+------------------+--------------------------------+--------------------------------+
......
```

in the file shared in slack https://raw.githubusercontent.com/score-spec/community-provisioners/refs/heads/main/score-k8s/10-redis-helm-upgrade.provisioners.yaml there is only one row to help determine what are the expected outputs 
```
OUTPUTS='{"resource_outputs":{"host":"%s-master", "port":"6379", "username":"", "password":"🔐💬%s_redis-password💬🔐"},"manifests":[]}'
```
what would be the best approach to have expected_outputs ?

issueDTO.title: Builder panics on malformed GCS private key instead of returning error
comments: Definitely looks like a good bug to fix to me -- thanks @HugoCasa

repository.description: Rust object_store crate
repository.name: arrow-rs-object-store

summary.main: When building a GCS client in `object_store`, if the provided private key is malformed, the builder panics instead of returning an error. This breaks expected behavior and makes error handling impossible.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the builder to return an error if the provided private key is malformed, not panic. This ensures that error handling is possible and the program remains stable.
summary.attemptedFixes: The fix can be implemented by modifying the code to handle malformed private keys by returning an error instead of panicking. This can be achieved by wrapping the `unwrap()` call in a `match` statement to handle potential errors.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is currently labeled as 'bug' and 'good first issue', indicating it's a significant issue suitable for a contributor to tackle. A pull request should be submitted targeting the main branch with before/after code changes if possible.
